insights.marketShareMention: Recognized Blackwell revenue across 25 customer categories, led by large cloud service providers representing ~50% of Data Center revenue
partnerships: U.S. government licensing for H20 products
regulatoryHeadwinds: Export controls on AI products

Geopolitical trade complexities
insights.summary: NVIDIA delivered strong Q2 performance driven by AI datacenter demand, with revenue up 56% YoY and net income up 59%. Blackwell architecture continues to ramp across multiple customer segments, demonstrating leadership in AI computing infrastructure.
keyQuotes: We continue to ramp our Blackwell architecture, which grew 17% sequentially
Strong year-on-year growth was driven by demand for our accelerated computing platform used for large language models
Future demand for our platform will depend on our ability to support, scale, and optimize the next generation of AI models

insights.marketShareMention: Blackwell architecture ramp expanded to all customer categories
regulatoryHeadwinds: US export controls on H20 chips to China
Potential new AI export restrictions
insights.summary: NVIDIA reported strong revenue growth driven by AI data center demand, but faced significant challenges from US export controls on H20 chips to China. The company took a $4.5 billion charge for excess inventory and anticipates potential revenue impact from export restrictions.
keyQuotes: The H20 export licensing requirements have impacted our current revenue and will also negatively affect our future revenue.
We believe the China AI market to be a significant opportunity and the existing and new export controls will greatly hinder our ability to address this opportunity.

regulatoryHeadwinds: US Export Controls
AI Regulations
insights.summary: NVIDIA delivered exceptional financial performance in fiscal 2025, driven by strong demand for AI and accelerated computing platforms, particularly in the Data Center segment. Revenue grew 114% to $130.5 billion, with net income rising 145% to $72.9 billion.
keyQuotes: Demand for our Hopper architecture drove our significant growth for the full year
We began shipping production systems of the Blackwell architecture in the fourth quarter of fiscal year 2025

insights.marketShareMention: competitive position strengthened in AI and data center markets
regulatoryHeadwinds: US export controls on AI chips to China
Potential licensing restrictions on semiconductor exports
insights.summary: NVIDIA delivered exceptional Q3 performance driven by AI and data center demand, with revenue up 94% year-over-year. The company continues to benefit from accelerated computing and generative AI trends, maintaining strong market positioning despite global trade challenges.
keyQuotes: Advancements in accelerated computing and generative AI models have driven increased demand for our Data Center systems
Demand for the Hopper architecture is strong and our H200 offering grew significantly in the quarter

insights.marketShareMention: Strong AI compute market positioning with Hopper and upcoming Blackwell architectures
regulatoryHeadwinds: US export controls to China
Licensing requirements for advanced AI chips
insights.summary: NVIDIA delivered exceptional Q2 performance driven by strong AI and Data Center demand, with revenue growing 122% year-over-year to $30 billion. The company is positioning itself at the forefront of AI computing with Hopper and upcoming Blackwell architectures.
keyQuotes: Hopper demand is strong, and shipments are expected to increase in the second half of fiscal 2025
We expect to ship several billion dollars in Blackwell revenue in the fourth quarter
Over the trailing four quarters, we estimate that inference drove over 40% of our Data Center revenue

insights.marketShareMention: Continued strong growth in AI data center market
regulatoryHeadwinds: US export controls on China shipments
Licensing requirements for advanced AI chips
insights.summary: NVIDIA delivered exceptional Q1 performance driven by massive AI demand, with Data Center revenue up 427% year-over-year. The company continues to lead in AI computing platforms and expects strong growth from Blackwell architecture.
keyQuotes: We expect the initial demand for Blackwell is well ahead of the projected supply for this fiscal year.
Large cloud providers continued to drive strong growth as they deploy and ramp NVIDIA AI infrastructure at scale
We have begun a broader and faster Data Center product launch cadence to meet a growing and diverse set of AI opportunities

insights.marketShareMention: Strong demand across enterprise software, consumer internet, automotive, financial services, and healthcare
regulatoryHeadwinds: US export controls on AI chips to China
Potential AI regulations
insights.summary: NVIDIA delivered exceptional financial performance in fiscal 2024, with Data Center revenue growing 217% driven by AI and generative AI demand. Strong execution across computing platforms and strategic positioning in AI technology.
keyQuotes: Demand for our data center systems and products surged in fiscal year 2024
We estimate that in fiscal year 2024, approximately 40% of Data Center revenue was for AI inference

insights.marketShareMention: Strong ramp of Hopper GPU architecture-based HGX platform from cloud service providers
regulatoryHeadwinds: US export controls on AI chip sales to China
Licensing requirements for A100 and H100 products
insights.summary: NVIDIA delivered exceptional Q3 results driven by surging AI demand, with Data Center revenue growing 279% year-over-year. The company is benefiting from massive investments in generative AI infrastructure and leading GPU technologies.
keyQuotes: Demand for our data center systems and products has surged over the last three quarters and our demand visibility extends into next year.
Strong sales of the NVIDIA HGX platform were driven by global demand for the training and inferencing of large language models, recommendation engines, and generative AI applications.

insights.marketShareMention: Strong AI and generative AI market positioning
regulatoryHeadwinds: US export controls on China
Additional licensing requirements for A100/H100 products
insights.summary: NVIDIA delivered exceptional Q2 performance driven by surging AI and data center demand, with revenue up 101% year-over-year. The company is at the forefront of generative AI technologies, with strong growth in compute and networking segments.
keyQuotes: Demand for our data center systems and products has surged over the last two quarters and our demand visibility extends into next year.
Strong demand for the NVIDIA HGX platform based on our Hopper and Ampere GPU architectures was primarily driven by the development of large language models and generative AI.

insights.marketShareMention: Strong demand from large consumer internet companies and cloud service providers
partnerships: Google Cloud offering NVIDIA L4 GPU
Dell Technologies Project Helix for enterprise AI solutions
regulatoryHeadwinds: US export controls impacting China sales
License requirements for A100 and H100 chips
insights.summary: NVIDIA delivered strong Q1 results driven by Data Center growth and generative AI demand. Revenue of $7.19B was down 13% year-over-year but up 19% sequentially, with particularly strong performance in AI and cloud computing platforms.
keyQuotes: Growing demand for generative AI and large language models using GPUs
We launched NVIDIA AI Foundations to help businesses create and operate custom large language models
Enterprise demand for GPU platforms was strong

regulatoryHeadwinds: US export restrictions on A100 and H100 products to China
Potential China licensing complications
insights.summary: NVIDIA experienced a challenging quarter with revenue declining 17% YoY, driven by weakening gaming and professional visualization segments. Data center remains a bright spot with 31% YoY growth, but US export restrictions to China and macroeconomic headwinds are creating significant near-term uncertainty.
keyQuotes: We believe the recent transition in verifying Ethereum cryptocurrency transactions from proof-of-work to proof-of-stake has reduced the utility of GPUs for cryptocurrency mining.
The U.S. government announced new restrictions on exports of our A100 and H100-based products to China, and any product destined for certain systems or entities in China.
These restrictions impacted third-quarter revenue, with the decline largely offset by sales of alternative products into China.
